hero_subtitle: how YouTube went from a hobbyist paradise to a whole industry
transcript_content: Hey guys, Jimmy here, welcome to my first YouTube video. I'm going to be very famous and get a lot of money from this, but I don't know how to yet. But hey, check this out, I found this really cool site, where apparently, they offer a course, on how to make a living off YouTube. It's quite expensive but at least you do save the one dollar. So um I definitely want to do this, let's check it out... Let's see what happens
intro_chat_2: [jimmy] I just spent 999$ on your course with my mom's credit card...
intro_chat_4: [jimmy] Can you help me make a lot of money on YouTube?
intro_chat_7: [vivian] Wait! What we CAN do is show you just how Youtube went from an hobby to an industry that makes many people tons of money. We are really good at what we do! We are super trustworthy and we have the best dataset! Check this out...
dataset_subtitle: Manoel Horta Ribeiro and Robert West (2011)
dataset_p1: The YouNiverse dataset is a large collection of English-language YouTube metadata from over 136k channels and 72.9M videos published between May 2005 and October 2019. YouNiverse also comprises channel-level time-series data with weekly subscriber and view counts, as well as a table specifying which videos a set of 449M anonymous users commented on.
sb_p1: The SponsorBlock database is the core of the open-source crowdsourced SponsorBlock browser extension. The extension aims to skip sponsor segments in YouTube videos. Users submit when a sponsor happens from the extension, and the extension automatically skips sponsors it knows about.
dataset_chat_1: [jimmy] Okay, fine. You know what you are doing. So how do I make money?
dataset_chat_2: [kaleb] To know that we know what we know, and that we do not know what we do not know, that is true knowledge...
dataset_chat_5: [daniel] He's trying to say that in order to master something, you need to first understand it. We have researched several questions, just for you, about what the data tell us.
learn_subtitle: Click any question to jump to that section **I KNOW THIS BIT IS A BIT UGLY**
q1_title: How have channels evolved from indie to professional?
q1_desc: What is the adoption curve of sponsorships between different categories?
q2_title: What enabled indie channels to become professional-minded?
q2_desc: At what subscriber thresholds do creators start showing "industry-like" patterns?
q3_title: How does a focus on professionalism affect engagement?
q3_desc: Does the number of views change after channels get sponsors?
section1_title: How have channels evolved from indie to professional?
section1_intro: YouTube grew from 338k uploads in 2008 to over 15.2 million in 2018. This rapid rise changed which categories became more or less common, and how creators approached their content.
viz_main_title: From Indie to Industry: How YouTube Grew from 2008 to 2018
viz_main_desc: In 2008, uploads were limited, categories were modest in size, and creators were mostly experimenting. As the years pass in the visualization, you can see the platform steadily filling with more activity. By 2018 the number of uploads reaches more than fifteen million. Some categories grow slowly, others take off, and together they trace YouTube's shift from a small creator space into a much larger and more organised environment.
viz_focus_desc: The chart follows the same story but from a different angle: what creators chose to include inside their videos. Links are grouped into three types: Monetization links such as amzn.to, amazon.com, patreon.com; Social links that lead to Twitter, Instagram, or Facebook; Content links to promote their own channels, previous videos on YouTube etc. From 2008 to 2018 all three lines rise. Year after year, more videos include at least one link. This simple pattern shows how creators changed their habits as the platform grew. In the early years many videos stood alone. Later, creators began pointing viewers to where they could support them, follow them, or find more of their work. It became common to add a link for income (monetization), a link for social presence (Social Links), or a link for more content. The two charts together tell a straightforward story: YouTube grew, and creators adapted. They posted more, reached wider audiences, and connected their videos to the rest of their online world.
viz_compare_desc: In this section you can compare categories side by side and see how their use of links changed over time. Once you select two categories, each chart shows four series: the share of uploads that include any link, and the shares that specifically include monetization, content, or social links. By placing two or more categories next to each other, you can see how differently creators in each space behaved. Some categories adopted social links earlier, some added monetization links later, and some steadily increased all types year after year. This view helps you explore these patterns in a clear, year-by-year way and understand how linking habits vary across the YouTube ecosystem.
dialogue_eddie_ask: Jimmy, what category do you want to explore?
dialogue_eddie_response_2: evolved over time. Check out the full visualization below!
dialogue_compare_ask: Want to compare two categories side by side? Pick Category A and Category B below!
section2_title: What enabled indie channels to become professional-minded?
section2_chat_1: [jimmy] Okay but how long is this going to take?! My mom is already wondering why her card is being declined.
section2_chat_2: [kaleb] All human wisdom is contained in these two words — wait and hope.
section2_chat_4: [kaleb] It's Dumas... Anyway, I hate to break it to you, but you might be waiting a while.
section2_chat_5:
[kaleb] The median time between posting your first video and obtaining your first sponsor is 1108 days or around 3 years! It also takes a median of 148 videos!
Note the logarithmic x axes. The right plot seems to follow a log-normal distribtion, whereas the left plot obtained $\lambda = 0.429\pm 0.017$ with a Box-Cox transformation, suggesting it is gamma-like.
section2_chat_6: [jimmy] Three years!!! I want to throw up. But what kind of stats do I need to get my first sponsor? Maybe if I buy enough bot accounts...
section2_chat_7: [kaleb] Ever heard of the sunk cost fallacy? A story for another day. Metrics your channel will likely need to reach before your first sponsor depend on the category of videos you want to make. How about you pick one?
section2_chat_9:
[kaleb] On median, you would need a total of around views and subscribers. Yould would also need to have published videos on median. In comparison, the medians of the global distributions over all categories are views, subscribers, and videos
Note the logarithmic x axes, and the logarithmic y axis for activity. All distributions seem to be log-normal, apart from activity, which seems to follow a power law. This might suggest that the activity has little-to-no effect on getting sponsored.
section2_chat_10: [jimmy] There are definitely some differences between categories, but I still don't know what to pick... And the longer I take to decide, the closer I get to having to explain a 1k transfer to "sheNaNigans incoporated". Aargh! Do I really have to choose or can I just pick whatever and switch once I get sponsored?
section2_chat_11:
[kaleb] Interesting strategy... It does happen but only quite rarely. If we look at the 6 months before the first sponsor and the 6 months after, and we compare the most common video categories in both periods, we get a sense of what kind of transitions people make.
Note the connections shown below are logarithmic.
section2_chat_12: [kaleb] I know you won't like this, but you may be able to pay your mom back over a longer period of time — like an investment! Except instead of asking the bank for a loan you went straight to the vault.
section2_chat_13: [jimmy] I don't know... How sustainable could it really be?
section2_chat_14: [kaleb] More than you might think! Look at the proportions of channels still active in 2025. The YouNiverse dataset only goes until 2019, so these data had to be collected using the YouTube API.
section2_chat_15: [eddie] Yeah it was a real pain to get. I have so many API keys now...
section2_chat_16: [kaleb] You can choose to look at all channels or compare sponsored and non-sponsored channels!
section2_chat_17: [kaleb] Notice how the sponsored channels seem to consistently be more active in 2025 than the non-sponsored ones? We can test this using a paired t-test between categories. The results show a significant ($p < 0.01$) 16.12% difference in activity! Whether this is caused by obtaining a sponsorship is a different question though...
section2_chat_18: [jimmy] So you can make YouTube your job!
section2_chat_20: [jimmy] I need to start right away! Tell me which sponsors pay the most?
section2_chat_21: [kaleb] Oof, that's a tough one... We don't really have the data on that. Although, we could look at which sponsors interact with which channels! Let's take channels A, B, and C. Let's say that A is sponsored by sponsors $\alpha$ and $\beta$, B by $\alpha$, $\beta$, and $\gamma$, and C by $\gamma$. Then A and B would have a connection of weight 2 between them and B and C a connection of weight 1. A and C would have no connection. Using this, we can build a graph.
section2_chat_22: [jimmy] How do you know who sponsored a channel though?
section2_chat_23: [kaleb] Good question! The short answer is painfully. You know how we mentioned earlier that video descriptions can contain URLs? Well we can look at those. However, a huge proportion of those URLs are shortened. URL shortening is when you use a service like bit.ly to make a URL shorter. Here comes the hard part: there is absolutely no way to figure out the link a shortened URL points to without pinging the shortener service.
section2_chat_24: [jimmy] Wow that sounds evil... How did you do it then?
section2_chat_25: [kaleb] Since we weren't going to hack the shortening services to steal their hashing algorithms, we had to use clever brute force. To minimise the amount of data we were requesting, we used HEAD requests with a "no redirect" policy. This meant that in the HEAD response header, we could extract the address the shortened link immediately redirected to. Since making thousands of requests a second looked suspicious to certain shortening services, we used an exponential backoff strategy. This worked by waiting a random, exponentially increasing amount of time between failed requests. That way, it would eventually wait long enough to reset any rate limits. We also ran multiple HTTP clients in parallel and tried proxy...
section2_chat_26: [jimmy] Okay I get it — it was a bad time. That was the last hurdle right?
section2_chat_27: [vivian] We wish! Having the full URLs is great, but we don't know which ones are linked to monetisation yet. Think about it, people put all sorts of links in their descriptions: WikiPedia articles, social media profiles, personal websites... The list goes on!
section2_chat_28: [jimmy] But then how did you figure it out? There must be millions of links!
section2_chat_29: [vivian] We tried a bunch of different strategies. The one we ended up going for was to use the TODO:insert_llm_name model with a handful of manual examples to classify the URLs as monetised or not.
section2_chat_31: [kaleb] Yes! Checkout the graph below. It's on a separate page because it runs preformance intense WebAssembly.
section2_chat_32: [kaleb] Notice you can toggle different colourmaps. Connectivity shows how many neighbours each node has (logarithmic scale), Category shows the channel category, Subscriber and Videos show the number of subscribers and videos (logarithmic scale), and Activity shows channels active in 2025 in blue, others in red. The most interesting colourmap is Leiden, which shows different community assignments by the Leiden algorithm. In short, it is a community detection algorithm that optimises the modularity of the graph.
section3_title: How does a focus on professionalism affect engagement?
